entries.title: Amazon cloud outage: online services hit, recovery uneven
entries.snippet:
On October 20, 2025, Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a major cloud outage, primarily affecting its US-EAST-1 data center region in northern Virginia. This disruption interfered with a wide array of online services across sectors including finance, social media, gaming, e-commerce, and education. The issue stemmed from a Domain Name System (DNS) problem that blocked access to DynamoDB’s API due to failures within AWS’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) internal network.

The outage impacted popular services like Amazon, Prime Video, Snapchat, Reddit, Venmo, Lyft, Fortnite, and Duolingo. Despite being gradually resolved, this incident highlighted the fragility of global digital infrastructure. AWS has suffered previous outages, notably in June 2023 and December 2021, also centered on its US-EAST-1 region. AWS, serving over a million customers monthly, reported $30.9 billion in revenue in Q2 2025, underlining the scale and critical role of its infrastructure in powering the modern internet.

entries.title: BlackRock's assets hit record $13.46 trillion on third-quarter markets rally
entries.snippet: BlackRock reported a surge in its third-quarter profits for 2025, driven by a strong rally in global markets that boosted fee income and increased its assets under management to a record $13.46 trillion, up from $11.48 trillion a year earlier. Investor enthusiasm was fueled by resilient U.S. consumer spending, moderating inflation, and the Federal Reserve's first interest rate cut of the year in September. These factors triggered significant inflows into BlackRock’s lower-cost index and fixed-income exchange-traded funds (ETFs), a key area of growth for the firm. Despite increased costs from acquiring HPS Investment Partners and softer performance fees, BlackRock saw long-term net inflows of $171 billion, highlighting the strength of its ETF business. Adjusted net income rose to $1.91 billion, or $11.55 per share, up from $1.72 billion, or $11.46 per share, in the same period last year.

entries.title: BlackRock's assets surge to $13.5tn
entries.snippet:
BlackRock's assets under management rose to a record $13.5 trillion in Q3 2025, driven by $205 billion in new client inflows and strong performance in global markets. Its iShares ETF platform surpassed $5 trillion, underlining its continuing growth. BlackRock has also significantly expanded its private markets footprint through nearly $30 billion in acquisitions of Global Infrastructure Partners, HPS Investment Partners, and Preqin. These moves contributed to $13.2 billion in new private market investments, including $7.9 billion in private credit, while its private markets unit now manages $321 billion and generated $951 million in quarterly fees, making up about 15% of total revenue.

Despite a 19% drop in reported net profit to $1.3 billion due to acquisition-related costs, adjusted net income reached $1.9 billion. Revenue rose 25% year-over-year to $6.5 billion, beating analyst estimates. CEO Larry Fink emphasized growing opportunities in the convergence of public and private markets, highlighting BlackRock’s strategic shift from ETF dominance toward expanding in private assets and technology. The firm also saw notable inflows into cash management ($34 billion) and digital assets ($17 billion), with its crypto funds, including a $93 billion bitcoin ETF, contributing significantly. Shares dipped less than 1% in pre-market trading.

entries.title: Fed posts record loss of $114.3 billion in 2023
entries.snippet: In 2023, the Federal Reserve reported a net negative income of $114.3 billion, marking a record loss attributed to the expenses associated with managing the short-term interest rate target. This follows a net income of $58.8 billion in 2022. The Fed emphasized that such losses do not hinder its operational or monetary policy capabilities. The Fed's aggressive interest rate hikes starting in spring 2022, aimed at controlling inflation, significantly increased its interest expenses. Interest expenses on banks' reserve balances rose to $176.8 billion, and payouts from the reverse repo facility increased to $104.3 billion. However, income from bonds remained stable at $163.8 billion. The losses are recorded as a deferred asset, which was $133.3 billion at the end of 2023 and had risen to $157.8 billion by March 2024. It may take years for the Fed to return to profitability and resume profit payments to the Treasury.

entries.title: Negative Shareholders Equity: What Does It Mean?
entries.snippet: Negative shareholders' equity occurs when a company's liabilities exceed its assets, indicating financial distress. It is calculated by subtracting total liabilities from total assets. Reasons for negative shareholders' equity include accumulated losses, large dividend payments, borrowing money, and amortization of intangible assets. Young companies might initially have negative equity due to borrowing for growth but could stabilize over time. Established companies with negative equity indicate significant financial instability and require careful evaluation. Notable companies, such as McDonald's and Starbucks, have experienced negative equity, but others like Lehman Brothers and Hertz filed for bankruptcy when they faced the same situation. Negative shareholders' equity signifies a risk and warrants a thorough investigation before investing.

entries.title: Google and Facebook will have more than half of UK digital ad market
entries.snippet: Google and Facebook are forecasted to dominate more than half of the UK's £8bn digital advertising market in 2015. Combined, their UK operations are expected to generate £4.1bn, capturing 50.8% of total digital ad spending, including ads on websites, smartphones, online videos, and social media. Google remains the leading digital publisher in the UK, holding a 90% market share in search-based advertising, and will see total revenues rise to £3.35bn in 2015. Facebook has seen significant growth, with its ad revenues predicted to increase by 29% next year, totaling £743m, primarily from display advertising. Facebook is expected to surpass Google in digital display advertising spend, accounting for 48% of the £2.3bn market. Mobile ad spending has been a critical growth driver, with the UK mobile ad market anticipated to reach £1.8bn this year and project to constitute 67% of digital ad investments by 2018. Twitter UK's ad revenue is expected to be £89.5m this year, mostly from advertising.

entries.title: Mary Meeker Says Advertisers Aren't Spending Enough on Mobile
entries.snippet: Mary Meeker's Internet Trends report highlights that Google and Facebook dominate US Internet advertising, holding a 76% share of ad growth. US Internet advertising overall grew by 20% from 2014 to 2015, driven mainly by a 66% increase in mobile ads, while desktop ads grew only by 5%. Despite this growth, Meeker argues that advertisers are under-investing in mobile ads, still favoring traditional media. The mobile ad market in the US is valued at $22 billion, with mobile usage accounting for 25% of people's time. However, mobile ads only represent 12% of total ad spending. Among millennials, Facebook, Instagram, and Snapchat are the most popular social networks. Meeker sees significant potential in Snapchat's brand filters, noting that users interact with sponsored lenses for an average of 20 seconds and these filters attract millions of views.

entries.title: U.S. digital ad revenue explodes during first half of 2017
entries.snippet: Digital advertising revenue in the U.S. saw a significant increase of 23% in the first half of 2017, according to PriceWaterhouseCoopers and the Interactive Advertising Bureau. Notably, mobile video ad revenue surpassed display video ad spending for the first time. However, the report does not account for the sector-specific challenges faced by digital publishers, such as layoffs and missed revenue targets. Analysts suggest that Google and Facebook may have captured 80-90% of the digital ad revenue growth. The top 10 companies controlled 75% of ad revenues in Q2 2017. Publishers' investment in video content is evident from the revenue data, though some, including Buzzfeed, Mashable, and Vice, are facing setbacks, possibly due to Google and Facebook's dominance in the video ad market.

entries.title: Justice Dept. sues Google over digital advertising dominance
entries.snippet: The Justice Department and eight states have filed an antitrust lawsuit against Google, accusing it of monopolizing the online advertising market and burdening advertisers, consumers, and the U.S. government. The lawsuit alleges that Google has engaged in anti-competitive practices for 15 years, acquiring rivals and manipulating ad auctions to force the use of its tools, thus stifling innovation and raising costs. The suit demands Google divest its digital ad control tools, while Google's parent company, Alphabet Inc., argues the action would stifle innovation and harm small businesses. This is part of broader efforts to rein in Big Tech's dominance. The case also aligns with similar antitrust actions in the European Union and previous suits within the U.S.

entries.title: US companies dominate the European cloud market - regional players are left fighting for scraps
entries.snippet: Despite significant growth in revenue, European cloud providers remain overshadowed by dominant U.S. tech firms. According to Synergy Research Group, U.S. giants like Amazon, Microsoft, and Google now command 70% of the European cloud market, while European providers retain just 15%, down from 29% in 2017. Although that 15% has stabilized since 2022, the market continues to be fiercely competitive. Size and investment are key factors in cloud success; U.S. companies are spending billions in Europe to expand infrastructure and support AI-driven demand. Microsoft alone is investing $80 billion globally, with significant portions allocated to European operations. European firms like SAP and Deutsche Telekom hold only 2% shares each, primarily serving local niche markets or partnering with U.S. providers. Sovereign cloud projects and regulatory challenges reflect growing concerns around data sovereignty. Despite a strained landscape, overall European cloud revenues have reached €36 billion in the first half of 2025, with strong growth driven by AI and public IaaS/PaaS services, especially in countries like Ireland, Spain, and Italy.

entries.title: Amazon, Microsoft, and Google Face Investigation Into Cloud Services by UK Regulators
entries.snippet: Amazon, Microsoft, and Alphabet's Google are being investigated by the U.K. Competitions and Markets Authority regarding cloud services. The authority is examining whether these providers complicate the process for businesses to switch or use multiple providers. Amazon and Microsoft dominate 70-80% of the U.K.’s cloud infrastructure market, which was worth £7-7.5 billion in 2022, while Google holds 5-10%. Concerns include high data transfer costs, incentives to retain customers, and tech barriers that impede migration or multi-platform usage. Amazon disputes these concerns, labeling them as misunderstandings. Both Amazon and Microsoft have expressed willingness to cooperate with the investigation, expected to conclude by April 2025. Additionally, French and EU regulators are also probing potential anti-competitive practices in the cloud computing sector. Following this announcement, shares of Amazon, Microsoft, and Alphabet saw a slight decline.

entries.title: Global AI adoption to push IT spending beyond $5.4 trillion in 2025
entries.snippet: Global IT spending is forecast to surpass $5.43 trillion in 2025, reflecting a 7.9% increase from 2024, primarily driven by rapid AI adoption, according to Gartner research. The data center systems segment is expected to see a dramatic 42.4% growth, marking it as the fastest-growing area due to heightened demand for AI-optimized servers, which now significantly outpace traditional server spending. Software spending is also projected to exceed the average growth rate at 10.5%, while other sectors such as devices (5.4%), IT services (4.4%), and communication services (2.1%) will show modest gains. Despite this expansion, overall IT spending growth is only slightly higher than 2024’s 7.4%, influenced by geopolitical uncertainties that delay new projects. Budgets remain intact but are being carefully evaluated, particularly for hardware and infrastructure, which could be impacted by market volatility. Recurring services like cloud computing are expected to remain stable. Analyst John-David Lovelock notes that ongoing AI initiatives continue to drive investment despite the economic caution.

entries.title: Debasing the 'debasement' trade
entries.snippet: The article explores the recent enthusiasm surrounding the so-called "debasement trade," where investors flock to assets such as gold, cryptocurrencies, and stocks, supposedly out of fear that U.S. fiscal policies and inflation will erode the dollar's value. While precious metals have surged significantly—gold up 50%—and some analysts point to growing U.S. debt and Federal Reserve rate cuts as evidence of dollar debasement, the bond and currency markets tell a different story. Treasury yields have fallen, not risen, and inflation expectations based on TIPS are low. The dollar, while weaker early in the year, has been relatively stable and even outperforming peers recently. Experts argue that major outflows from the dollar or Treasuries, which would mark true debasement fears, are not apparent. Instead, the asset rallies may stem from diversification strategies, momentum buying, or political uncertainty, rather than a broad loss of confidence in the U.S. economy. Thus, the article suggests that the "debasement trade" may be more narrative than reality, and market behavior doesn't fully support fears of systemic dollar debasement.

entries.title: US bond investors weigh 'convexity' risk in recent Treasury yield decline
entries.snippet: The drop in U.S. Treasury yields has led to speculation that 'convexity' buying by mortgage portfolio managers and insurance companies contributed to the decline. Convexity buying helps offset the impact of mortgage refinancing when interest rates fall. The benchmark U.S. 10-year yield influencing various borrows has not moved significantly since bottoming at 4.10% in early March after a substantial decline. Convexity hedging is always occurring but varies in intensity, especially when rates fall, leading to shifts in mortgage holdings to balance portfolios. Currently, about 64% of outstanding mortgages are locked in at rates below 4%, but 16% with rates above 6% could be quickly refinanced. For portfolios, investors counter negative MBS convexity by purchasing Treasuries, Treasury futures, or engaging in interest rate swaps. Active MBS hedgers have significantly decreased since their peak in 2002, which likely limits the impact of convexity moves. Additionally, recent tightening in the spread between 10-year interest rate swaps and Treasury yields signifies active convexity hedging, raising short-term implied volatility in longer-dated swaptions.

entries.title: What Are Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS)?
entries.snippet:
Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS) are U.S. government bonds introduced in 1997 designed to safeguard investors from inflation. Unlike traditional Treasury bonds, TIPS adjust their principal based on changes in the Consumer Price Index (CPI). As inflation rises, the bond’s principal increases, which in turn raises the interest payments since they are calculated on the adjusted principal. In deflationary periods, the principal decreases, reducing interest payments, but investors are guaranteed to receive at least the original principal at maturity.

TIPS are issued in five-, ten-, and thirty-year terms, and can be purchased directly from the U.S. Treasury through TreasuryDirect or via brokers and mutual funds/ETFs. Their lower initial interest rates and potential tax implications (as interest and inflation-adjusted increases are federally taxed) are cons to consider. However, they are ideal for retirees, conservative investors, and long-term savers who want to preserve purchasing power.

Despite being intended for inflation protection, TIPS underperformed in 2022 due to rising interest rates. They are best used as part of a long-term investment strategy rather than short-term inflation hedges. While yields can be negative in real terms, TIPS remain popular due to their government backing and inflation-indexed returns.

entries.title: Big Profits and High Prices: There Is a Connection
entries.snippet: President Biden has frequently criticized large corporations for contributing to inflation through practices like price gouging, deceptive pricing, and maintaining high profit margins. Corporate profit margins increased from 13.4% in late 2019 to 17% by mid-2022, driven by pandemic-related supply constraints. Although supply issues have mostly been resolved, profit margins remained high at 16.4% in 2023, the highest since the 1960s outside the pandemic period. High margins can contribute to inflation by keeping prices elevated even when costs decrease, a pattern confirmed by research suggesting that prices rise quickly with increasing costs but fall slowly when costs decrease. Biden's focus on corporate greed aligns with a broader narrative of holding companies accountable, similar to historical figures like Teddy Roosevelt.

entries.title: Profitability is next sacrifice at inflation altar
entries.snippet: The battle against inflation involves central bankers like Jerome Powell and Christine Lagarde urging corporate leaders, including Mark Zuckerberg and Bernard Arnault, not to transfer rising wage costs to consumers, as it could reignite price increases. This pressure on companies is expected to dampen profitability. The spike in corporate profits post-pandemic and amid geopolitical tension has significantly contributed to inflation. For example, companies like Exxon Mobil and PepsiCo recorded unprecedented profits while inflation surged. Central banks are now intervening, with a focus on keeping wage growth in check to prevent further inflation. Despite a slight decline in euro zone corporate profitability, U.S. companies' margins remain high, complicating the Fed's efforts to manage inflation. Ultimately, central banks seem poised to keep interest rates high until corporate profit margins decrease, hoping to achieve a deflationary effect.

entries.title: Who Wins a Brokerage Price War?
entries.snippet:
In October 2019, major online brokers like Charles Schwab, E*TRADE, and Fidelity cut equity commissions to zero, sparking a significant shift in the industry. Previously, brokers had gradually reduced commissions and expanded commission-free trades on select exchange-traded funds (ETFs). The recent move to eliminate stock and ETF commissions removes a key revenue source but brokers still generate income through other means such as interest on idle cash, options trading fees, and payment for order flow. While free trading benefits customers by reducing costs, brokers leverage services like cash sweep programs, managed accounts, and lending stock to short sellers to maintain revenue.

The reduction in trading commissions primarily stimulates market participation by new investors, emphasizing that zero commissions are not necessarily an end goal but part of broader revenue strategies in place by brokers. Established firms, capable of integrating multiple financial services under one umbrella, are well-positioned to benefit. Schwab's strategic focus on removing commission barriers aligns with a growing trend of commission-free investing as an entry point for individuals seeking to invest small amounts for long-term financial goals.

entries.title: How retail traders squeezed Wall Street for bets against GameStop
entries.snippet:
During the COVID-19 pandemic, a surge in retail trading, fueled by lockdown savings, stimulus money, low interest rates, and the rise of free trading apps, led to dramatic stock market movements. Retail investors' share of equity order flows rose significantly, and platforms like eToro saw massive user growth. Many retail traders began investing in stock options, amplifying price movements.

This newfound retail activity targeted struggling companies like GameStop, sparking a price surge of over 1600% that caught Wall Street off guard. Conversations on forums like Reddit's WallStreetBets played a major role in driving hype and coordination among these individual investors. Hedge funds like Melvin Capital, heavily shorting GameStop, suffered major losses as retail investors triggered a short squeeze, forcing institutional traders to buy back shares at inflated prices.

While some investors profited, analysts warned of asset bubbles and the risks of speculative trading, especially with margin lending. If the market turned, retail investors heavily exposed to overvalued stocks or debt could face significant financial losses.

entries.title: Robinhood's Vlad Tenev has led a trading revolution to become a new Wall Street power
entries.snippet:
Vlad Tenev, co-founder and CEO of Robinhood, has spearheaded a retail trading revolution, transforming his company into a dominant force on Wall Street. Since launching commission-free mobile trading in 2013, Robinhood has accrued 25.9 million active accounts and a market valuation of $73 billion in 2025. Tenev foresaw the shift toward mobile and active investing, capitalizing on rising smartphone use and dissatisfaction with traditional brokerages. His innovation, notably the "payment for order flow" model, pressured competitors like TD Ameritrade and E-Trade to eliminate trading fees, sparking a surge in retail investing.

Despite early meteoric growth, Robinhood faced challenges, including platform outages and regulatory scrutiny, particularly after the 2021 meme-stock trading freeze. The company adapted by expanding into crypto, launching a premium subscription service, and enhancing its platform with features like 24-hour trading and educational tools.

After posting its first profitable year in 2024 with $3 billion in revenue, Robinhood has regained user trust and solidified its status in the financial landscape. Tenev now collaborates with the U.S. government on initiatives like "Invest America," aiming to empower future generations with early exposure to investing, underscoring his vision of a financial system increasingly driven by retail participation.

entries.title: 'Investors should back the AI maximalists'
entries.snippet:
The article argues that despite prevailing skepticism in the UK investment community about the sustainability of the AI-driven tech rally, investors should support "AI maximalists" who see artificial intelligence as a transformative technology rather than a speculative bubble. The UK's investors largely anticipate a repeat of the 2000 tech crash, whereas in the US, the dominance of the "Magnificent Seven" tech stocks in the S&P 500 is underpinned by strong earnings. Ben Rogoff, who manages the £5 billion Polar Capital Technology Trust, holds a bullish view on AI and has structured the trust’s portfolio accordingly, leading to significant outperformance in recent months.

Rogoff emphasizes that transformative periods inherently involve volatility, comparing the current AI boom to past industrial revolutions. He highlights rapid growth in AI adoption, corporate spending, and its long-term disruptive potential. Despite criticisms and perceived risks, Rogoff sees AI as offering unprecedented opportunities akin to 19th-century railroads. The trust’s diversified portfolio is heavily weighted toward large-cap US tech firms and remains selective, excluding companies without strong AI positioning. Ultimately, the article suggests that dismissing the AI revolution could be a costly mistake for investors.

entries.title: Breaking Up With Big Tech Is Hard to Do. How to Truly Diversify.
entries.snippet:
A recent report by DataTrek Research reveals that the S&P 1500, which includes small-, mid-, and large-cap stocks, offers little diversification compared to the S&P 500. The top 10 holdings—dominated by big tech firms, Berkshire Hathaway, and JPMorgan Chase—represent a similar market weight in both indices: 40.5% in the S&P 500 and 37.5% in the S&P 1500. Sector composition also remains largely the same, with technology stocks comprising over 33% of the S&P 1500. Consequently, passive index ETFs tied to the S&P 1500 do not offer significant diversification away from tech-driven large caps. 

Despite only slightly lower returns compared to the S&P 500, small- and mid-cap stocks remain attractive due to lower valuations and potential for gains. The Russell 2000 is up 12.8% in 2025 and shows strong momentum, while the S&P Small Cap 600 is also positive. Experts suggest actively investing in smaller companies, which are trading at lower P/E ratios compared to the large-cap-heavy S&P 1500. Popular small- and mid-cap holdings include Sprouts Farmers Market and Cal-Maine Foods. Ultimately, true diversification may require looking beyond traditional broad-market ETFs.

entries.title: US tech stock tumble highlights risk of market reliance on megacaps
entries.snippet: The recent decline in US tech stocks underscores the risk of the market's heavy reliance on a few large companies, particularly those in the AI sector. The emergence of a low-cost Chinese AI model, DeepSeek, has rattled markets and caused significant drops in major tech stocks, notably Nvidia. This has raised concerns among investors about the concentration of investment in megacaps and the potential for selloffs to have outsized impacts on market indices like the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100. While some market participants see this as a potential inflection point for a shift in market leadership, others believe the selloff may be an overreaction. The market's dependence on these large tech firms highlights both the opportunities and risks associated with concentrated investments. This week will be further tested by quarterly results from major companies like Apple, Microsoft, Meta Platforms, and Tesla.

entries.title: TSMC moves up 2nm production plans in Arizona -  CEO also hints at further site expansion beyond $165 billion commitment
entries.snippet:
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) is accelerating its 2nm chip production timeline in Arizona, driven by strong AI-related demand from U.S.-based clients. CEO C.C. Wei noted that the company is upgrading its technologies more quickly than planned and hinted at further expansion, including the potential acquisition of additional land near its existing Arizona facility. This move suggests a build-out of a complete Gigafab cluster capable of producing 100,000 12-inch wafers monthly, including packaging, testing, and support infrastructure.

Originally, 2nm production was set to begin by 2030, but due to rising demand, particularly from companies like Apple, Nvidia, AMD, and Broadcom, TSMC plans to advance the timeline by roughly a year. The expansion is part of TSMC’s broader investment in the U.S., which already includes a $165 billion commitment. Furthermore, to support future workforce needs, TSMC is growing its internship program in Arizona, increasing available slots from 130 to 200. Despite global semiconductor supply chain uncertainties due to the U.S.-China trade tensions, TSMC remains confident in long-term demand, particularly from AI and consumer electronics segments.

entries.title: It's the Most Indispensable Machine in the World-and It Depends on This Woman
entries.snippet: Brienna Hall is a customer-support engineer at ASML, the company solely responsible for producing indispensable extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography machines. These machines are critical for manufacturing the most advanced microchips in the world. Hall works in a highly controlled environment at Micron Technology’s semiconductor fab in Boise. Her role is to maintain and troubleshoot these complex and expensive machines, which are crucial for the functioning of countless devices like smartphones and computers. These EUV machines use cutting-edge science to achieve incredibly fine resolutions needed for modern microchips. ASML has a small but critical market presence, with its success hinging on dedicated engineers like Hall, trained extensively to ensure the EUV tools are operational. Customer-support engineers like Hall are vital to keeping the semiconductor industry running smoothly, due to the machines' complexity and the significant impact any downtime can have on production.

entries.title: US-China Trade Tensions Threaten Europe's Biggest Tech Company
entries.snippet: ASML, a Dutch company located in the small town of Veldhoven, has become a crucial player in the global technology industry by building machines that produce semiconductor chips. It is Europe’s largest public tech company by market cap, with a near-monopoly on the advanced extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography systems used to create semiconductor chips. However, ASML's growth is being threatened by US-China trade tensions, which have resulted in the company being blocked from selling its most advanced machines to China. China is a fast-growing market in semiconductor manufacturing, and attempts to restrict its access to global supply chains have led to concerns that China will develop its own alternative to ASML. The US imposes export controls over security concerns, potentially threatening ASML's current revenues and capability to fund further research and development. This geopolitical friction poses a significant challenge to ASML's future dominance in the semiconductor industry.

entries.title: Álvarez-Pallete, reelegido presidente de GSMA hasta diciembre de 2026
entries.snippet:
José María Álvarez-Pallete, presidente ejecutivo de Telefónica, ha sido reelegido como presidente de la GSMA hasta diciembre de 2026. La GSMA es una asociación que reúne a los principales grupos de telecomunicaciones y organiza el Mobile World Congress en Barcelona. Álvarez-Pallete asumió el cargo en febrero de 2022, siendo el primer español en ocupar dicho puesto. Su reelección reconoce su gestión en un momento crucial para el sector, destacada en el Informe Draghi.

Durante su mandato, ha promovido el lanzamiento de Open Gateway y el uso responsable de la tecnología y la inteligencia artificial, creando una hoja de ruta común para la industria. Ha subrayado la importancia de cerrar la brecha digital para asegurar los beneficios socioeconómicos de la digitalización a todos los sectores de la sociedad.

La GSMA agrupa a más de 1.100 empresas del sector, contribuyendo 5,7 billones de dólares al PIB mundial en 2023 y empleando a cerca de 35 millones de personas. Aproximadamente el 69% de la población mundial estaba suscrita a servicios móviles a fines de 2023, con un rápido crecimiento en la penetración de Internet móvil.

entries.title: 5G Technology: Which Country Will Be the First to Adapt?
entries.snippet: Countries worldwide are rapidly adopting 5G technology to remain competitive globally. By 2035, 5G could generate 22.3 million jobs and $13.2 trillion in economic output. The United States led the way, with the FCC opening high-band spectrums and major carriers like AT&T and Verizon rolling out 5G in numerous cities. South Korea is at the forefront with 5G in 85 cities, thanks to collaboration among carriers SK Telecom, LG Uplus, and KT Corp. Sweden and Estonia began 5G tests in 2018, focusing on IoT and industry digitalization. Turkey, still in trial phases, aims to boost domestic production with affordable tech services. Japan launched 5G by 2020, spearheaded by NTT DOCOMO's early efforts and government support, promising speeds 100 times faster than LTE. China, second to the US in city coverage, aims for 460 million connections by 2025, overcoming slow 4G implementation with extensive 5G testing and infrastructure development.

entries.title: Mobile industry slashes global carbon emissions despite 4X increase in worldwide data traffic - here's why it matters
entries.snippet: Between 2019 and 2023, the global mobile industry successfully reduced its operational carbon emissions by 8% despite a fourfold increase in mobile data traffic and a 9% rise in mobile connections. This progress contrasts with a 4% overall increase in global emissions during the same period. Energy efficiency improvements and a shift toward renewables, such as solar and battery storage, contributed to this reduction, alongside discontinuing outdated networks and diesel generators. Regional leaders included Europe, North America, and Latin America, which achieved emission cuts of 56%, 44%, and 36%, respectively. China, the world's largest mobile market, recorded a 4% decline in 2024 alone. However, the industry must accelerate its efforts to achieve a 7.5% annual reduction through 2030 to stay aligned with net-zero goals. Scope 3 emissions—mainly from supply chains—remain a challenge, while increased consumer interest in circularity and refurbished phones, which generate up to 90% fewer emissions, offers promising potential. The refurbished market is projected to reach $150 billion by 2027. Sustaining progress requires broader support, including improved access to renewable energy, clear policy guidance, and stronger collaboration across the industry ecosystem.

entries.title: Fed's Williams skeptical neutral rate has risen
entries.snippet: El presidente del Banco de la Reserva Federal de Nueva York, John Williams, expresó el miércoles su escepticismo sobre el aumento del nivel de las tasas de interés neutrales en impacto económico. Williams se refirió a R-Star, la tasa de interés neutral real que equilibra la economía a largo plazo, esencial para determinar si la política monetaria es estimulante o restrictiva. Aunque algunos economistas creen que ha aumentado debido a cambios post-pandemia, Williams se mostró escéptico y comentó que cualquier aumento de R-Star debe superar las fuerzas que lo han empujado hacia abajo durante décadas, como las tendencias en demografía y crecimiento de la productividad. Además, mencionó que debido a la alta incertidumbre sobre R-Star, no se debe depender demasiado de sus estimaciones para definir políticas monetarias. Williams no hizo comentarios sobre la perspectiva de la política monetaria y la economía en sus comentarios preparados para una conferencia del Banco Central Europeo en Sintra, Portugal.

entries.title: Facebook hit with another EU sanction
entries.snippet: On May 18, 2017, the EU fined Facebook €110 million ($122 million) for providing misleading information during the 2014 review of its acquisition of WhatsApp. This penalty marks a significant issue, as experts believe Facebook's data analysis capabilities give them an unfair advantage in making strategic investments. The fine follows a ruling the previous day by French and Dutch courts that Facebook violated European data privacy standards, resulting in a sanction of €150,000. When acquiring WhatsApp, Facebook assured the EU that it wouldn't combine user data from both platforms. However, in 2016, Facebook announced the use of WhatsApp's data for targeted ads, which contradicts their earlier statements. Although Facebook claims the errors were unintentional, Europe’s stringent stance on tech companies' privacy and antitrust practices indicates growing regulatory challenges for U.S. tech firms operating in European markets. Despite the fines being relatively small in comparison to Facebook's $27 billion annual revenue, the increased scrutiny may constrain its expansion efforts, potentially shifting focus to emerging markets.

entries.title: Meta had 'monopoly power' after buying rival apps, FTC says
entries.snippet: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has launched a high-profile antitrust trial against Meta, formerly Facebook, accusing the tech giant of gaining "monopoly power" through its acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp in 2012 and 2014. The FTC's lawyer, Daniel Matheson, argued that Meta's purchases stifled competition and allowed the company to dominate the social media market, citing internal communications from CEO Mark Zuckerberg that revealed concerns about potential threats from these rival apps. Meta is said to have 85% of market share in app usage, though the company disputes this, claiming its share drops below 30% when factoring in competitors like TikTok and YouTube. The trial is seen as a major test of the Trump administration's willingness to challenge Big Tech, under new FTC chair Andrew Ferguson. If Meta is found guilty, it could be forced to divest Instagram and WhatsApp. Meta has denied monopolistic practices, arguing that competition remains fierce and that it improved the platforms while keeping them free. Analysts note the FTC faces challenges, especially after the initial case was dismissed in 2021 for lacking sufficient legal ground. Key figures expected to testify include Zuckerberg, Sheryl Sandberg, and leaders from rival companies.

entries.title: Facebook Seeks EU Approval of WhatsApp Deal to Avoid Antitrust Headaches
entries.snippet: Facebook has requested an antitrust review by the European Commission for its $19 billion acquisition of WhatsApp. This strategy aims to circumvent potential antitrust investigations from multiple European countries where national telecom companies might push for the deal to be blocked. WhatsApp, which charges $1 per year for unlimited messaging, has had a significant impact on the traditional text messaging industry, especially outside the U.S. In the U.S., the Federal Trade Commission approved the deal in April with the stipulation that Facebook and WhatsApp must notify and seek permission before sharing user information beyond their current privacy settings.

entries.title: Apple and Alphabet Led the S&P 500 in Stock Buybacks
entries.snippet: In the second quarter, Apple, Alphabet, and Meta Platforms led the S&P 500 in stock buybacks. The total repurchases for the companies in that index amounted to $235.9 billion, an increase of 8% from the same period a year before but a slight decrease of 0.4% from the first quarter. Apple set a quarterly record with $28.8 billion in buybacks, marking the largest repurchase program of any U.S. company over the past 10 years. Alphabet followed with $15.7 billion, and Meta Platforms with $9.5 billion. The total buybacks for the S&P 500 amounted to $877.5 billion over the last 12 months, up 8% from the previous year. Dividends also increased by 7% year over year to $153.4 billion in the second quarter. Although buybacks rose in dollar terms, they now represent a smaller percentage of the overall S&P 500 index value due to recent stock surges. The buyback yield was 1.9%, down from 2.9% in 2022, while the S&P 500 dividend yield was 1.3%. The combined total yield decreased to 3.2% compared to previous years.

entries.title: Stock Buybacks To Top $1 Trillion In 2025, Goldman Says
entries.snippet: Stock buybacks for S&P 500 companies are forecasted to surpass $1 trillion in 2025, according to Goldman Sachs strategists. This prediction is driven by robust earnings in Big Tech companies such as Apple, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Meta Platforms. For 2024, S&P 500 buybacks are expected to reach $925 billion, marking a 13% annual increase. The trend is anticipated to continue into 2025 with a projected 16% rise to $1.075 trillion. Earnings growth, particularly from megacap tech companies, and a favorable economic outlook are cited as primary drivers. The Magnificent Seven, which includes tech giants like Apple and Microsoft, are expected to significantly contribute to this buyback surge. Additionally, falling Treasury yields and potential Fed rate cuts in mid-2024 are poised to create more conducive conditions for buybacks. Although some companies, such as Meta, have initiated dividends, the trend towards increased buybacks remains strong, with Big Tech companies authorized to repurchase substantial amounts of their stock.

entries.title: Retail traders plough $67bn into US stocks while investment giants flee
entries.snippet: In 2025, individual investors have directed nearly $70 billion into US stocks, contrasting with large investment firms that are reducing their market exposure due to concerns over President Donald Trump's policies. Despite a 2% decline in the S&P 500 and an 8% drop in its tech sector, retail traders remain optimistic, continuing to buy on market dips, a strategy that has proven effective in previous years. This confidence persists even with market volatility exacerbated by Trump's unpredictable tariff plans and competition from the Chinese AI startup DeepSeek. Data shows that retail investors have predominantly been net buyers, exemplified by significant investments in companies like Tesla and Nvidia, while large investors have markedly cut their US stock holdings. Some experts warn that the enthusiasm of retail traders could be reminiscent of past market downturn signals, such as the dot-com bubble.

entries.title: Deflationary pressures persist in China on weak demand, overcapacity
entries.snippet:
Deflationary pressures continue to challenge China's economy, with both consumer (CPI) and producer prices (PPI) falling in September 2025, signaling muted domestic demand and overcapacity. The CPI dropped 0.3% year-on-year, slightly less than August's 0.4% decline, while the PPI fell 2.3%, narrowing from a 2.9% fall in the previous month. Food prices, especially pork, declined significantly amid weak demand and government measures to curb oversupply. Despite a rebound in exports, renewed trade tensions with the U.S. and a sluggish property sector are weighing heavily on consumer confidence.

Core inflation, which excludes food and fuel, rose to 1%, a 19-month high, indicating some underlying price stability. However, the combination of falling prices and slowing holiday spending suggests weak consumer sentiment. Economists suggest that while policymakers are increasingly concerned about deflation, their current supply-side strategies may not succeed without stronger demand-side interventions.

Previous government efforts, including rate cuts and liquidity injections, have yet to reverse deflationary trends, and further monetary easing is anticipated, possibly in November. However, caution remains due to the risk of inflating asset bubbles, particularly in the stock market. Trade tensions and price wars in key sectors like autos further complicate recovery prospects.

entries.title: China's factory-gate deflation worst in 2 years as  trade war bites
entries.snippet: In June 2025, China recorded its worst producer price deflation in nearly two years as the economy struggled with global trade tensions and weak domestic demand. The Producer Price Index (PPI) dropped by 3.6% year-on-year, surpassing May’s 3.3% decline and reflecting the deepest fall since July 2023. Ongoing trade uncertainties, driven in part by U.S. tariffs from President Trump, have dampened export expectations and pressured export-oriented industries. Meanwhile, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) slightly increased by 0.1%, its first rise in five months, helped by a rebound in industrial consumer goods prices. However, domestic demand remains sluggish amid a protracted housing slump, prompting businesses to offer heavy price discounts and policymakers to consider further stimulus. E-commerce giants like Alibaba and JD.com have launched aggressive subsidy strategies to boost market share. While core inflation rose to 0.7%, the highest in over a year, analysts foresee a potential easing of inflation and expect China's central bank to cut interest rates again in the fourth quarter to support the economy. Market responses to the data were cautious, with mixed movements on Chinese stock indices.

entries.title: Value of China's exports falls sharply on sliding prices
entries.snippet: China's export value fell by 7.5% in March compared to the previous year, significantly below analysts' expectations of a 2.3% contraction. This decline was attributed to reduced prices of Chinese goods despite record-high export volumes, challenging Beijing's efforts to invigorate the economy amidst a property sector slump. Overcapacity, particularly in sectors favored by industrial policy like electric vehicles and solar panels, has driven prices down, benefiting China's global market share but alarming foreign competitors. Seasonal effects from the Lunar New Year and exchange rate factors also influenced the export figures. Meanwhile, China aims to boost domestic demand and meet its 5% GDP growth target for 2024, countering accusations of overcapacity and dumping cheap goods abroad. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is visiting China to discuss market access for foreign companies amidst these dynamics.

entries.title: Netflix's ad, gaming bets in focus as investors seek clarity on pay-off
entries.snippet:
Netflix's $120 billion stock rally in 2025 is under scrutiny as the company prepares to report its Q3 results, with investors focusing on whether its investments in advertising and video games can sustain growth. A strong content slate, including hits like “KPop Demon Hunters” and the second season of “Wednesday,” is expected to drive Netflix’s biggest revenue boost in over four years. However, some analysts worry about the streamer’s long-term growth potential, especially after it ceased reporting subscriber counts and pivoted attention to financial metrics.

Netflix has invested around $1 billion into building its gaming venture, offering over 120 mobile titles, yet it has seen minimal impact on user engagement—less than a 0.5% increase in time spent, per Omdia. Analysts note Netflix’s lack of iconic IP as a barrier to gaming success, unlike competitors such as Warner Bros. Discovery. The ad-supported tier, with about 94 million users and contributing modestly to revenue, is expected to become a key driver of future growth. Overall, Q3 revenue is projected to rise 17.2% to $11.51 billion, with net profit climbing 27% to $3.01 billion, but concerns linger over the profitability and scalability of newer ventures.

entries.title: Amazon Prime Video outpaces Netflix growth after Premier League debut
entries.snippet: Amazon Prime Video experienced remarkable growth in the UK, attributing much of its success to live-streaming Premier League matches. In the fourth quarter, Prime Video saw a 35% increase in subscribers, reaching 7.14 million homes. This surge was Amazon's best performance since its UK launch six years ago. Despite Netflix leading the UK market with 12.35 million subscribers and 20% annual growth, Amazon capitalized on popular shows and sports content to attract new subscribers. Notably, Amazon gained 1.86 million new users in 2019, the most substantial annual increase since 2014. Meanwhile, Now TV, Sky's streaming service, experienced an 8% subscriber drop between the third and fourth quarters, ending the year with 1.69 million subscribers. For the first time, over half of UK households held subscriptions to at least one of these services, with 14.3 million homes subscribing to either Netflix, Prime Video, or Now TV.

entries.title: Netflix Crowned King of Streaming With More Than a Third of Peak Traffic
entries.snippet: Netflix has become the predominant streaming service, accounting for over 34% of peak wired download traffic in North America, an increase from 31.6% in late 2013, according to Sandvine. The next closest service, YouTube, reaches only 13.19%. This growth bodes well as Netflix plans a price increase for new subscribers. In mobile networks, YouTube leads with 17.26% traffic, with Netflix far behind at 4.55%. The rise in Netflix's usage reflects the growing trend of cord cutting, where users prefer streaming services over traditional pay-TV. Cord cutters now average 212GB of data per month and stream about 100 hours of video, accounting for 53.9% of total traffic. This trend alarms TV networks and providers, who are responding with their own internet video packages. However, a positive outcome for the industry is the decline in file-sharing traffic, now only 8.3%, down from 31% six years ago.

entries.title: How AI Fueled Black Friday Shopping This Year
entries.snippet: Este año, la inteligencia artificial está transformando el Black Friday. Las ventas de comercio electrónico en Estados Unidos alcanzaron los $10.8 mil millones, un incremento del 10.2% respecto a 2023, según Adobe Analytics. Los chatbots de IA generativa impulsaron un aumento del 1,800% en el tráfico de sitios minoristas, ayudando a los compradores a encontrar ofertas y realizar compras más rápidamente. Los minoristas que usan IA vieron un 9% de aumento en sus tasas de conversión. Salesforce informó un crecimiento del 31% en el uso de servicios de chat en línea, señalando ventas de $17.5 mil millones, un aumento del 7% interanual. Las compras móviles representaron el 55% de las ventas en línea, con un aumento del 12.1% en el uso de billeteras móviles y del 41% en servicios de BNPL. Las tiendas físicas registraron una caída del 3.2% en el tráfico. La región del Medio Oeste vio una caída del 7% debido a tormentas de nieve. Las ventas en línea de juguetes aumentaron un 622%, con grandes descuentos en juguetes, electrónicos, y ropa. Con el Cyber Monday en el horizonte, se espera que las ventas sigan aumentando, con proyecciones de hasta $40.6 mil millones para la semana cibernética.

entries.title: Report: Thanksgiving Day online sales hit record $5.1 billion
entries.snippet: Thanksgiving Day online sales in 2020 set a new record of $5.1 billion, marking a significant 22% increase compared to the previous year, according to data from Adobe Analytics. The shift towards online shopping was driven by consumers avoiding physical retail stores due to COVID-19 concerns. Adobe's data, which monitors real-time online transactions at the top 100 U.S. retailers, highlighted that nearly half of the purchases were made via smartphones. Furthermore, Adobe predicts the entire holiday shopping season (from November 1 to December 31) will generate a total of $189 billion in sales.

entries.title: Target, Walmart shoppers seek home goods, grocery delivery online
entries.snippet: U.S. online spending has rebounded, driven by high gas prices, convenient delivery options, and numerous deals. In the first quarter of 2024, e-commerce sales comprised 15.9% of total U.S. retail sales, nearing their pandemic peak. Target and Walmart have both reported significant growth in online sales. Target saw a 1.4% increase, aided by same-day delivery options and curbside pickup. Walmart experienced a 22% surge, supported by an expanded merchandise range and last-mile delivery services favored over in-store pickups. Retailers like Lowe's have utilized partnerships with delivery services like DoorDash and Shipt to boost online sales. Subscription services offering perks, such as Walmart+ and Target Circle 360, are pivotal. Overall, U.S. consumers spent $331.6 billion online from January to April 2024, a 7% increase from the previous year, driven by economic factors and ongoing promotional events.

entries.title: 'Of course it's a bubble': AI start-up valuations soar in investor frenzy
entries.snippet:
Over the past year, valuations for ten major lossmaking AI start-ups — including OpenAI, Anthropic, and xAI — have surged nearly $1 trillion amid an investor frenzy, raising concerns of a burgeoning bubble in the private market. Venture capitalists in the U.S. have spent $161 billion on AI so far in 2025, accounting for two-thirds of their total funding. Companies with modest revenue, like $5 million in annual recurring revenue, are commanding valuations exceeding $500 million — multiples that surpass even the 2021 investment highs.

Key investors argue that bubbles, while risky, are necessary for technological revolutions, pointing to major historical tech gains following speculative investment periods. While some fear unrealistic valuations and widespread losses, others believe AI's potential, especially with aspirations toward artificial general intelligence (AGI), justifies the risk. OpenAI, for instance, has seen explosive annual revenue growth to $13 billion just three years after launching ChatGPT.

However, the heavy dependence of public markets on private AI companies adds systemic risk — deals with chipmakers like Nvidia and AMD have influenced their stock valuations based on AI demand projections. Investors remain divided but ultimately maintain faith that a few winners will shape multitrillion-dollar markets in the future.

entries.title: Tiger Global closes $2.2bn fund well below its original target
entries.snippet: Tiger Global has finalized its latest venture capital fund at $2.2 billion, significantly under its original $6 billion target announced in 2022. Despite its previous success, including raising a $12.7 billion fund in 2021 and investing in companies such as ByteDance, Shein, and Stripe, the fundraising climate has shifted. High interest rates and decreased valuations in private markets have reduced investor enthusiasm for venture capital. The slow commitment pace, closing with just $200 million additional since mid-2023, highlights this challenge. Additionally, the departure of key executive Scott Shleifer has affected the fund's marketing and timelines. Tiger Global remains hopeful about its significant investments like Stripe, Databricks, and ByteDance eventually going public when market conditions improve.

entries.title: Venture Capital Investments in AI Surged in 2024
entries.snippet: In 2024, venture capital investments saw modest growth, increasing to $314 billion, a 3% rise from 2023, though still significantly lower than the peak in 2021. A standout trend was the surge in funding for AI companies, which comprised nearly a third of all global venture capital investments and grew by over 80% compared to the previous year. Major AI firms like xAI, Databricks, Anthropic, and OpenAI dominated the funding landscape, raising a combined $40 billion. The U.S. captured 57% of the global investments, with a notable concentration in Silicon Valley, reversing a recent trend of investment dispersion to other regions. Despite the overall slow year for acquisitions and IPOs, the market ended positively with the ServiceTitan IPO. The outlook for 2025 is promising, with potential regulatory changes and strong performance of recent IPOs indicating a more favorable environment for new public companies.

entries.title: U.S. COVID-19 Stimulus and Relief
entries.snippet: The COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on the U.S. economy, resulting in a recession, high unemployment, and a steep decline in GDP. In response, both the Trump and Biden administrations implemented numerous fiscal policies, while the Federal Reserve deployed a variety of monetary policies to stabilize the economy. The Fed's measures included interest rate cuts, quantitative easing, repurchase operations, and the creation of special funding facilities to ensure liquidity and credit availability. Significant federal relief packages, such as the CARES Act, facilitated direct financial support to individuals and businesses through stimulus checks, unemployment benefits, and loans. Later legislation, including the American Rescue Plan Act, continued to provide substantial financial assistance. Despite these efforts, federal stimulus checks ended in 2022, with some states continuing limited stimulus programs. Post-pandemic, strategies evolved to address rising inflation and economic recovery, marking significant fiscal and monetary efforts to mitigate the pandemic's economic damage.

entries.title: Tapering: How, Why, and When the Fed Does It and Impact on Financial Markets
entries.snippet:
Tapering is the process by which central banks reduce the monetary stimulus they provided to boost economic recovery. It usually follows a quantitative easing (QE) program where the central bank purchases assets to inject money into the economy. The Federal Reserve (Fed) may taper by changing the discount rate, reserve requirements, or reducing its asset holdings. Communicating tapering plans transparently helps set market expectations and minimize uncertainty. However, announcements of tapering often lead to increased bond yields and decreased equity markets, known as "taper tantrums."

The Fed's tapering response to the COVID-19 pandemic included reducing asset purchases and stopping "easy money" policies, shifting to manage rising costs. The process began in December 2021, with significant asset holdings reductions by June 2022.

Tapering is distinct from tightening, which involves raising interest rates and selling assets to slow down economic growth and curb inflation. The shift to tapering can help prevent asset bubbles and inflation if handled gradually to avoid triggering a recession, as demonstrated following the 2007-2008 financial crisis.

entries.title: Fed pledges to continue buying bonds until economy makes "substantial" progress
entries.snippet: The Federal Reserve has decided to maintain current interest rates at 0%-0.25% and continue purchasing at least $120 billion in bonds monthly until significant progress is made towards maximum employment and price stability goals. Fed Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the commitment to the bond-buying program and reassured continued monetary policy support for a considerable time. Although stock prices initially dropped after the announcement, they rose during Powell’s press conference. The Fed believes bond purchases support market function and credit flow. Powell downplayed concerns about high stock price levels by relating current valuation metrics to historically low Treasury returns. The perception of Fed policy over time, rather than meeting-to-meeting actions, is crucial, according to Lou Brien, rates strategist at DRW Trading.

entries.title: Biden rolls out budget plan, challenges GOP to follow suit
entries.snippet: President Joe Biden unveiled a budget proposal to cut deficits by $2.9 trillion over the next decade, while challenging Republicans to present their own plan. The proposal includes raising $4.7 trillion through increased taxes on the wealthy and corporations and $800 billion in savings from program changes. Biden's plan also includes $2.6 trillion in new spending on programs benefiting the middle class, families, and the elderly. Key features include restoring the expanded child tax credit, capping insulin prices, and adjusting taxes on the wealthy. Biden's proposal aims to support programs without raising taxes on those earning under $400,000 and contends that GOP lawmakers have yet to provide a counteroffer, maintaining their calls for a balanced budget without specifying spending cuts or increased revenues. The budget reflects tensions in U.S. economic policy, including the potential expiration of Trump-era tax cuts and the need to address the national debt, which could exacerbate an already fragile economy if no agreement is reached.

thoughts.content:
I’m laying out the causes of the tech/market boom from 2013 to the present, ranked roughly by their impact:

1) Monetary policy & low rates – leading to higher valuations.
2) Profit cycle & tax changes – boosting corporate profits.
3) Buybacks & capital return.
4) Mobile + digital advertising – mobile ads surpassing TV.
5) Cloud & SaaS growth – AWS soaring.
6) Semiconductor advancements.
7) Market structure – rise of passive indexing.

I’ll cite the relevant sources carefully for accuracy.

parts:
Here’s a concise causal map of the 2013→today tech-led market boom (minimizing Gen-AI, per your note). I’ve ranked the drivers by how much they explain the *broad* and *persistent* rise in tech earnings, margins, and multiples.

financeturn20finance0

## 1) Exceptionally easy money (2013–2021) lifted present values and risk appetite  
- The U.S. lived with near-zero policy rates through Dec 2015, then again in 2020–2021, while large-scale asset purchases compressed term premia and credit spreads—classic tailwinds for long-duration equities (growth/tech). The Fed ended QE3 in Oct 2014, hiked the first time on Dec 17 2015, and later bought **$120B/month** in 2020–2021 before tapering. citeturn19search11turn0search5turn19search7  
- Real yields (10-yr TIPS) spent long stretches near/under zero in 2020–2022—mechanically boosting DCFs for cash-flows arriving far in the future (i.e., secular growers). citeturn5search1turn5search0

## 2) A profit-cycle shock: margins and after-tax earnings structurally higher  
- U.S. corporate profits ran unusually high as a share of national income in the late-2010s and again post-2020. That wasn’t just “tech hype”—it showed up in BEA data and Fed analysis. citeturn6search2turn6search5  
- The **2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act** permanently cut the federal corporate rate from 35%→21% (effective 2018) and added full expensing for short-lived assets; both raised after-tax earnings and tilted capital allocation toward buybacks. citeturn0search1turn0search11

## 3) Buybacks + capital return became a dominant net bid under cheap capital  
- S&P 500 repurchases approached **$1T** on a trailing-12-month basis multiple times (e.g., 2024–2025), with mega-caps (Apple/Alphabet/Meta) leading. Net *issuance* by U.S. corporates has often been negative—amplifying EPS and supporting prices. citeturn14search20turn14search8turn2search7  
- The 1% excise tax on buybacks (effective 2023) hasn’t reversed the trend; proposals to raise it to 4% are pending but not enacted. citeturn21search10turn21search1

## 4) Mobile + digital ads S-curve (2013–2019) monetized attention at global scale  
- U.S. smartphone ownership moved from **~56% (2013)** to **~91% (2024)**; globally, usage exploded as well. That user-time migration funded Alphabet/Meta and the broader ad-tech stack. citeturn3search6turn3search0  
- By **2018**, *mobile* ad spend surpassed TV in the U.S.; Google+Facebook captured a majority of U.S. digital ad dollars in that period. citeturn3search4turn3search2

## 5) Cloud computing & the SaaS business model (2014→) scaled profits predictably  
- Public-cloud spend has compounded at ~20%+ in recent years; Gartner put **2024** end-user spend near **$675B** (from ~$560B in 2023). The recurring/usage model raised visibility and margins across software. citeturn4search2  
- AWS is a clean microcosm: revenue rose from **$4.6B (2014)** to **$108B (2024)**, with large operating contribution—illustrating the infra layer’s profitability. citeturn1view0  
- Investor playbooks (Rule-of-40, etc.) institutionalized premium multiples for efficient, recurring-revenue names. citeturn10search1

## 6) Semiconductors quietly enabled it all  
- **7 nm (2018)** and **5 nm (2020)** node ramps at TSMC, unlocked by EUV tools from ASML, improved performance/Watt for phones, servers and accelerators; that underpins mobile, cloud and now AI. citeturn9search0turn9search1turn9search2

## 7) Market structure: passive flows + index concentration  
- Index funds/ETFs’ share of long-term fund assets climbed from **~19% (2010)** to **~48% (2023)**, creating steady mechanical demand into the largest constituents. citeturn0search8  
- Concentration then amplified returns: the “Mag-7” carried a disproportionate share of S&P 500 performance in 2023–2024. citeturn8search1

## 8) Retail participation surge and frictionless trading  
- Zero-commission moves (Schwab et al., 2019) + app brokers + PFOF reshaped micro-structure and participation; the SEC’s 2021 staff report documented those incentives and their effects. citeturn7search3turn7search13  
- Pandemic stimulus + time at home produced bursts of retail flow (e.g., meme-stocks), which—while episodic—helped pull forward liquidity and risk appetite. citeturn7search11turn7news30

## 9) COVID digitization step-change (non-AI)  
- Firms reported a *multi-year* acceleration of digital adoption in 2020; U.S. e-commerce sales jumped **~43% in 2020** alone—permanent demand pulled into the online channel benefitted platforms, payments, logistics, and software. citeturn17search0turn17search2turn17search1

## 10) A long globalization hangover kept goods inflation low and margins supported  
- Research across IMF/BIS/FRBNY links deeper global value chains and China’s rise to downward pressure on tradable-goods prices in the 2000s–2010s. That backdrop sustained consumer surplus and corporate margins entering the 2010s bull run. citeturn15search0turn15search4turn15search7

---

### What this *actually* did to returns  
Two reinforcing channels dominated:  
**(A)** *Earnings power* rose (scale, margins, lower taxes); **(B)** *Multiples* expanded when real rates collapsed and risk premia compressed. The **SPY** chart above shows the compounding outcome across 2013→2025 with only two major drawdowns (’18 QT/trade, ’22 inflation/hikes), both reversed when policy or profits pivoted. citeturn19search7

---

## Common pitfalls in the narrative (pushback you should want)  
- “It was just low rates.” Not sufficient: cross-sectional dispersion shows firms with superior unit economics and network effects captured most of the gains; profits and cash flows genuinely grew. citeturn6search6  
- “It was only AI.” The bulk of market-cap creation pre-2023 came from mobile, cloud, and ad monetization S-curves, then *AI* arrived as an *accelerant*, not the foundation. citeturn3search4turn4search2  
- “Buybacks just engineered EPS.” True at the margin, but the scale persisted even after the 1% excise tax and remains correlated with cash flow growth concentrated in mega-caps. citeturn21search10turn14search8

---

## Forward-looking (non-AI) supports vs. risks

**Supports**
- Cloud & software still mid-penetration in lagging sectors; public-cloud spend growth remains double-digit (even excluding Gen-AI). citeturn4search2  
- 5G and mobile payments keep nudging time-spent and commerce online, preserving the ad-/subscription base. citeturn11search6  
- U.S. capital-markets depth (ETFs, liquidity) continues to funnel savings into equities—especially via passive. citeturn0search8  

**Risks (watch these)**
- **Sustained positive real rates**: if r* or term premium resets higher for longer, multiples compress; 10-yr TIPS are the cleanest real-time gauge. citeturn5search1turn12search2  
- **Policy**: higher corporate rates or a bigger buyback tax would dent after-tax EPS and capital return. citeturn0search1turn21search1  
- **Antitrust/regulation**: late-cycle cases (ads, app stores, cloud) can raise costs and curb M&A-driven consolidation that previously reinforced moats. citeturn3news33  
- **Geopolitics/supply chain**: semiconductor and data-center buildouts hinge on ASML/TSMC nodes and foundry geopolitics; forced re-routing raises capex and risk. citeturn9search2turn9search0

---

### Bottom line  
From 2013 onward, the *combination* of (i) ultra-easy money, (ii) structurally higher profits (tax + scale economics), (iii) business-model S-curves (mobile ads, cloud/SaaS), (iv) buybacks + passive flows, and (v) enabling silicon cycles explains most of the tech-led market boom. AI is today’s accelerant, but the foundation was laid a decade earlier—and much of it (cloud mix-shift, platform economics, capex into compute) still has room to run, provided real rates and regulation don’t flip the regime.

supporting_websites.title: How retail traders squeezed Wall Street for bets against GameStop
supporting_websites.snippet:
During the COVID-19 pandemic, a surge in retail trading, fueled by lockdown savings, stimulus money, low interest rates, and the rise of free trading apps, led to dramatic stock market movements. Retail investors' share of equity order flows rose significantly, and platforms like eToro saw massive user growth. Many retail traders began investing in stock options, amplifying price movements.

This newfound retail activity targeted struggling companies like GameStop, sparking a price surge of over 1600% that caught Wall Street off guard. Conversations on forums like Reddit's WallStreetBets played a major role in driving hype and coordination among these individual investors. Hedge funds like Melvin Capital, heavily shorting GameStop, suffered major losses as retail investors triggered a short squeeze, forcing institutional traders to buy back shares at inflated prices.

While some investors profited, analysts warned of asset bubbles and the risks of speculative trading, especially with margin lending. If the market turned, retail investors heavily exposed to overvalued stocks or debt could face significant financial losses.

items.title: Justice Dept. sues Google over digital advertising dominance
items.snippet: The Justice Department and eight states have filed an antitrust lawsuit against Google, accusing it of monopolizing the online advertising market and burdening advertisers, consumers, and the U.S. government. The lawsuit alleges that Google has engaged in anti-competitive practices for 15 years, acquiring rivals and manipulating ad auctions to force the use of its tools, thus stifling innovation and raising costs. The suit demands Google divest its digital ad control tools, while Google's parent company, Alphabet Inc., argues the action would stifle innovation and harm small businesses. This is part of broader efforts to rein in Big Tech's dominance. The case also aligns with similar antitrust actions in the European Union and previous suits within the U.S.
